message.content:
cs.CL, cs.AI, cs.LG, cs.IR, cs.NE 

This paper is likely to belong to the arXiv CS sub-category of cs.CL (Computation and Language) as it deals with natural language processing and specifically focuses on abstractive summarization. Additionally, the paper mentions the use of a sequence-to-sequence (seq2seq) framework, which is a common approach in NLP. 

The paper also employs reinforcement learning techniques, which suggests that it could potentially belong to the cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence) sub-category. 

Furthermore, the use of a critic network and a binary classifier to assess the quality of generated summaries suggests that the paper could also belong to the cs.LG (Machine Learning) sub-category. 

The paper's focus on generating high-quality summaries also suggests that it could belong to the cs.IR (Information Retrieval) sub-category, as summarization is a common task in this field. 

Finally, the use of policy gradient methods for parameter learning suggests that the paper could also belong to the cs.NE (Neural and Evolutionary Computing) sub-category, as this is a common approach in neural network training.
